steps.title: Filters
steps.content:
Using Filters in Excel

Download and use the Movie Sample Database file to practice these skills.

Filters help you temporarily hide data that doesn't meet your criteria. Let's learn how to use them effectively.

Complete steps to apply filters:

  1. Select the column header you want to filter
  2. Go to the Data tab in the ribbon
  3. Click the Filter button (funnel icon)
  4. Click the dropdown arrow that appears in your column header
  5. You can now:
    • Uncheck "Select All" and manually select values you want to see
    • Use the Search box to find specific values
    • Sort A to Z or Z to A directly from here
    • Use number filters (Greater than, Less than, etc.) for numerical data

You can press CTRL + A to select all columns and click the filter button to apply multiple filters.

To clear a filter:

  1. Click the filter dropdown arrow
  2. Click "Clear Filter from [Column Name]"
  3. Or use Data tab → Clear button to remove all filters at once

quiz.question: What happens to rows that don't meet your filter criteria?
options: They are hidden but still exist

steps.title: Deleting Data/Columns
steps.content:
Cleaning Unnessecary Data

Not all columns are necessary for analysis. Learning to remove irrelevant data helps keep your workbook focused and manageable.

To delete a single column:

  1. Right-click the column letter at the top
  2. Select "Delete" from the context menu
  3. The column will be removed and surrounding columns will shift left

To delete multiple columns:

  1. Hold Ctrl and click each column letter you want to delete
  2. Right-click any selected column letter
  3. Choose "Delete" from the context menu

Alternative method:

  1. Select column(s) to delete
  2. Go to Home tab
  3. Click the Delete button in the Cells group
  4. Select "Delete Sheet Columns"

Important: Before deleting columns:

  • Consider creating a backup of your workbook
  • Verify you won't need this data later
  • Ensure no formulas in other columns reference this data

quiz.question: What is the best way to delete multiple columns that aren't next to each other?
options: Delete them one at a time
Hold Ctrl while selecting columns, then delete

steps.title: Finding and Replacing
steps.content:
Finding and Fixing Data Errors

Clean data is crucial for accurate analysis. Let's learn how to identify and fix common data issues.

Complete steps to clean data:

  1. Select your data range (Ctrl + A selects all)
  2. Go to the Home tab
  3. Click Find & Select in the Editing group
  4. Choose Go To Special
  5. In the dialog box that appears:
    • Select "Blanks" to find empty cells
    • Click OK
  6. With blank cells selected, you can:
    • Hit the tab button on your keyboard to go through all the related cells
    • Right-click → Delete Row to remove rows with blanks
    • Enter a specific value into all blanks at once
    • Use formulas to fill blanks based on other cells

To find and replace text errors:

  1. Press Ctrl + H to open Find & Replace
  2. Enter the error text (like "N/A" or "#N/A")
  3. Leave Replace With blank for removal, or enter a replacement value
  4. Click Replace All

steps.title: Sorting Data
steps.content:
Organizing Data with Sort

Sorting helps identify anomalies and organize data logically.

Complete sorting process:

  1. Select all your data (Ctrl + A)
  2. Go to the Data tab
  3. Click the Sort button in the Sort & Filter group
  4. In the Sort dialog box:
    • Check "My data has headers" if your first row contains column names
    • Choose the column to sort by
    • Select the sort order (A to Z, Z to A, or custom)
    • Click Add Level to sort by additional columns
  5. Click OK to apply the sort

Quick Sort Options:

  1. Select a single column
  2. Use the A-Z or Z-A buttons in the Data tab for immediate sorting
  3. Right-click a column → Sort for basic sorting options

Pro Tip: Always select all related data before sorting to maintain data integrity across rows.
